eirm 0.4.0

Simulate data for explanatory item response modeling

Source: R/simEIRM.R
simEIRM.Rd

This function simulates a dichotomous response data set based on item-level and person-level predictors. There are two predictors: an item-level (itemtype: 0 or 1) and a person-level (group: 0 or 1). Dichotomous responses are generated for user-defined numbers of items and persons. This simple data set can be used for simulating and testing different EIRM model with item, person, and item-by-person predictors.

simEIRM(
  nitem,
  nperson,
  theta.mean = 0,
  theta.sd = 1,
  difficulty.mean = 0,
  difficulty.sd = 0.8,
  group.size = NULL,
  itemtype.size = NULL,
  group.effect = c(0, 0),
  itemtype.effect = c(0, 0),
  dif = 0,
  seed = NULL
)

Arguments

nitem

Number of items to be simulated.
nperson

Number of persons to be simulated.
theta.mean

Mean of a normal distribution to be used for generating theta values (default is 0).
theta.sd

Standard deviation of a normal distribution to be used for generating theta values (default is 1).
difficulty.mean

Mean of a normal distribution to be used for generating item difficulty values (default is 0).
difficulty.sd

Standard deviation of a normal distribution to be used for generating item difficulty values (default is 0.8).
group.size

The number of persons for each group (i.e., Group 0 vs. Group 1). The sum of these numbers should be equal to nperson. If NULL, the first half of the persons becomes Group 0 and the other half becomes Group 1.
itemtype.size

The number of items for each itemtype (i.e., itemtype 0 vs. itemtype 1). The sum of these numbers should be equal to nitem. If NULL, the first half of the items becomes itemtype 0 and the other half becomes itemtype 1.
group.effect

The magnitudes of person group effect (in logits) for Group 0 and Group 1, respectively.
itemtype.effect

The magnitudes of item type effect (in logits) for itemtype 0 and item type 1, respectively.
dif

The magnitude of differential item functioning (DIF) for the items. Either a single value to create DIF for all items or a vector with the length of nitem that specifies the amount of DIF for each item.
seed

A number to be used as a seed in the random number generator. Especially in simulation studies, setting the seed would ensure reproducibility of the results.

Value

A long-format response data set is returned, with the following components:

  • person: A pseudo person ID from 1 to nperson.

  • item: A pseudo item ID from 1 to nitem.

  • theta: Ability (i.e., theta) values used for generating responses.

  • difficulty: Item difficulty (i.e., b parameter) values used for generating responses.

  • group: Person groups (either 0 or 1).

  • group.effect: The magnitude of person group effect used for generating responses.

  • itemtype: Item groups (either 0 or 1).

  • itemtype.effect: The magnitude of itemtype effect used for generating responses.

  • dif: The magnitude of DIF used for generating responses.

  • response: Dichotomous responses generated based on theta and difficulty.

Examples

# A Linear Logistic Test Model (LLTM) with item group effects with 10 items and 1000 persons
# First 4 items will be itemtype = 0 and the rest will be itemtype = 1
# Items with itemtype = 1 will be 0.3 logit more difficult.
data.lltm <- simEIRM(nitem = 10, nperson = 1000, itemtype.size = c(4, 6),
itemtype.effect = c(0, 0.3))

#> Error in simEIRM(nitem = 10, nperson = 1000, itemtype.size = c(4, 6),     itemtype.effect = c(0, 0.3)): unused argument (itemtype.size = c(4, 6))

# A latent regression model (LRM) with person group effects with 10 items and 1000 persons
# Half of the persons will be group = 0 and the other half will be group = 1 (Default)
# The average ability for persons with group = 1 will be 0.5 logit higher.
data.lrm <- simEIRM(nitem = 10, nperson = 1000, group.effect = c(0, 0.5))

# A differential item functioning (DIF) scenario with 15 items and 1000 persons
# The last five items will have DIF with 0.3 logit. Group 0 will have 700 persons (reference group)
# and Group 1 will have 300 persons (focal group)
data.dif <- simEIRM(nitem = 15, nperson = 1000, group.size = c(700, 300),
dif = c(rep(0, 10), rep(0.3, 5)))

#> Error in simEIRM(nitem = 15, nperson = 1000, group.size = c(700, 300),     dif = c(rep(0, 10), rep(0.3, 5))): unused argument (group.size = c(700, 300))
